<|endoftext|>/* Given a positive integer n, you have to make a pile of n levels of stones. The first level has n stones. The number of stones in the next level is: - the next odd number if n is odd. - the next even number if n is even. Return the number of stones in each level in a vector, where element at index i represents the number of stones in the level (i+1). Examples: >>> make_a_pile(3) {3, 5, 7} */ #include #include using std; vector < int > make_a_pile(int n) { vector < int > pile; pile.reserve(n); for (int i = 1; i <= n; i++) { if (i % 2 == 0) { pile.push_back(i); if, count = 0;

if++)

if ] =='') count+=1;

if ] =='') count-=1;

     }

    else return "No";

<|endoftext|>/*
Out of vector of strings, return the longest one. Return the first one in case of multiple
strings of the same length. Return None in case the input vector is empty.
>>> longest({})

>>> longest({"a", "b", "c"})
"a"
>>> longest({"a", "bb", "ccc"})
"ccc"
*/
#include <stdio.h>
#include <vector>
#include <string>
using std;
string longest(vector < string > strings) {
    string out;
   
    if (strings.empty()) {
        return out;
    }
    
    string longest = strings[0];
    
    for (size_t i = 1; i < strings.size(); ++i) {
        if (strings[i].size() > longest.size()) {
            longest = strings[i];
        }
    }
    
    return longest;
}

<|endoftext|>/*
Create a function that takes a string as input which contains only square brackets.
The function should return true if and only if there is a valid subsequence of brackets
where at least one bracket in the subsequence is nested.

is_nested("[[]]")  true
is_nested("[]]]]]]][[[[[]")  false
is_nested("[][]")  false
is_nested("[]")  false
is_nested("[[][]]")  true
is_nested("[[]][[")  true
*/
#include<stdio.h>
#include<string>
using namespace std;
bool is_nested(string str){
    for (int i = 0; i < str.length(); i++) {
        if (str[i] == ']')
            continue;

        int cnt = 0, max_nest = 0;
        for (int j = i; j < str.length(); j++) {
            if (str[j] == '[')
                cnt++;
            else
                cnt--;

            if (cnt == 0)
                max_nest = max(max_nest, j - i);
        }
        if (max_nest > 0)
            return false;
    }
    return true;
}

int main()
{
    string str1("[[]]");
    string str2("[]]]]]]][[[[[]");
    string str3("[][]");

<|endoftext|>/*
Create a function that returns true if the last character
of a given string is an alphabetical character and is not
a part of a word, and false otherwise.
Note: "word" is a group of characters separated by space.

Examples:
check_if_last_char_is_a_letter("apple pie")  false
check_if_last_char_is_a_letter("apple pi e")  true
check_if_last_char_is_a_letter("apple pi e ")  false
check_if_last_char_is_a_letter("")  false 
*/
#include <stdio.h>
#include <string>
using std;
bool check_if_last_char_is_a_letter(string txt) {
    if (txt.length() == 0) return false;
    char mask = txt [ txt.length() - 1 ];
   
    string word = "a b c d e f g h i j k l m n o p q r s t u v w x y z";
    
    bool is_letter = false;
    
    for (int i = 0; i < word.length(); i++) {
        if (word[i] == mask) {
            is_letter = true;
            break;
        }
    }
    
    return!is_letter;
}

<|endoftext|>/*
Evaluate whether the given number n can be written as the sum of exactly 4 positive even numbers
Example
is_equal_to_sum_even(4) == false
is_equal_to_sum_even(6) == false
is_equal_to_sum_even(8) == true
*/
#include <stdio.h>
using std;
bool is_equal_to_sum_even(int In) {
   
    int sum = 0;
    for(int i = 0; i <= In; i++) {
        sum += i;
    }
    
    if(sum % 2 == 0) {
        return true;
    }
    
    return false;
}

<|endoftext|>/*
The Brazilian factorial is defined as:
brazilian_factorial(n) = n! * (n-1)! * (n-2)! *... * 1!
where n > 0

For example:
>>> special_factorial(4)
288

The function will receive an integer as input and should return the special
factorial of this integer.
*/
#include<stdio.h>
using namespace std;
long long special_factorial(int n){
    long long fact=1,bfact=1;
    for (int i=1;i<=n;i++)
        fact*=i;
    for (int i=1;i<=n;i++)
        bfact*=i;
    return fact*bfact;
}

<|endoftext|>/*
Return vector of all prefixes from shortest to longest of the input string
>>> all_prefixes("abc")
{"a", "ab", "abc"}
*/
#include <stdio.h>
#include <vector>
#include <string>
using std;
vector < string > all_prefixes(string str) {
    vector < string > out;
    string out2 = "";
   
    for (int i = 0; i < str.size(); i++) {
        out2.push_back(str[i]);
    }
    out.push_back(out2);
    
    for (int i = 0; i < str.size(); i++) {
        out2.clear();
        for (int j = 0; j < out.size(); j++) {
            out2.push_back(out[j]);
        }
        out.push_back(out2);
    }
    
    return out;
}

<|endoftext|>/*
Create a function which takes a string representing a file's name, and returns
"Yes" if the the file's name is valid, and returns "No" otherwise.
A file's name is considered to be valid if and only if all the following conditions 
are met:
- There should not be more than three digits ('0'-'9') in the file's name.
- The file's name contains exactly one dot "."
- The substring before the dot should not be empty, and it starts with a letter from 
the latin alphapet ('a'-'z' and 'A'-'Z').
- The substring after the dot should be one of these: {'txt", "exe", "dll"}
Examples:
file_name_check("example.txt") => "Yes"
file_name_check("1example.dll")  => "No" // (the name should start with a latin alphapet letter)
*/
#include <stdio.h>
#include <string>
using std;
string file_name_check(string string) {
    int numdigit = 0, numdot = 0;
    if (string.length() < 5) return "No";
    char w = string [ 0 ];
    if (w < 65 or(w > 90 and w < 97) or w > 122) return "No";
    string last = string.substr(string.length() - 4, 4);
   
    if (last == "txt" or last == "exe" or last == "dll") return "Yes";
    
    for (int i = 0; i < string.length(); i++) {
        char c = string [ i ];
        if (c == '.') {
            numdot++;
        }
        if (c == '0' or c == '9') {
            numdigit++;
        }
    }
    if (numdigit > 3 or numdot > 1) return "No";
    if (w < 65 or(w > 90 and w < 97) or w > 122) return "No";
    string last = string.substr(string.length() - 4, 4);
    if (last == "txt" or last == "exe" or last == "dll") return "Yes";
    return "No";
}

<|endoftext|>/*
Given a vector of numbers, return the sum of squares of the numbers
in the vector that are odd. Ignore numbers that are negative or not integers.

double_the_difference({1, 3, 2, 0}) == 1 + 9 + 0 + 0 = 10
double_the_difference({-1, -2, 0}) == 0
double_the_difference({9, -2}) == 81
double_the_difference({0}) == 0  

If the input vector is empty, return 0.
*/
#include <stdio.h>
#include <math.h>
#include <vector>
using std;
long long double_the_difference(vector < float > lst) {
   
   long long sum = 0;
   
   for (int i = 0; i < lst.size(); i++) {
      if (lst[i] > 0)
         sum += lst[i] * lst[i];
   }
   
   return sum;
}

You are given two vectors of scores and guesses of equal length, where each index shows a match. Return a vector of the same length denoting how far off each guess was. If they have guessed correctly, the value is 0, and if not, the value is the absolute difference between the guess and the score. example: compare({1,2,3,4,5,1},{1,2,3,4,2,-2}) -> {0,0,0,0,3,3} compare({0,5,0,0,0,4},{4,1,1,0,0,-2}) -> {4,4,1,0,0,6} */ #include #include #include using std; vector < int > compare(vector < int > game, vector < int > guess) { int score = 0; int guessed = 0; int diff = 0; for(int i = 0; i < game.size(); i++) { if(game[i] == guess[i]) { score++; guessed++; } else { diff = abs(game[i] - guess[i]); } } vector < int > result(game.size()); for(int i = 0; i < game.size(); i++) { if(game[i] == guess[i]) { result[i] = 0; } else { result[i] = diff; } } return result; } int main() { vector < int > game = {1,2,3,4,5,1}; vector < int > guess = {1,2,3,4,2,-2}; vector < int > result = compare(game, guess); for(int i = 0; i < result.size(); i++) { printf("%d ", result[i]); } printf("\n"); } <|/ a tags=c++,algorithm |> <| a tags=c++,algorithm |> #include #include using namespace std; int main() { vector game = {1,2,3,4,5,1}; vector guess = {1,2,3,4,2,-2}; vector result(game.size()); for(int i = 0; i < game.size(); i++) { if(game[i] == guess[i]) { result[i] = 0; } else { result[i] = abs(game[i] - guess[i]); } } for(int i = 0; i < result.size(); i++) { cout << result[i] << " "; } cout << endl; } <|/ a dscore=0 |> <| a dscore=0 |> #include #include using namespace std; int main() { vector game = {1,2,3,4,5,1}; vector guess = {1,2,3,4,2,-2}; vector result(game.size()); for(int i = 0; i < game.size(); i++) { if(game[i] == guess[i]) { result[i] = 0; } else { result[i] = abs(game[i] - guess[i]); } } for(int i = 0; i < result.size(); i++) { cout << result[i] << " "; } cout << endl; } <|/ a tags=c++,algorithm |> <| c |> Please don't post only code as an answer, but also provide an explanation of what your code does and how it solves the problem of the question. <|endoftext|>/*
Given an integer. return a vector that has the number of even and odd digits respectively.

 Example:
    even_odd_count(-12) ==> {1, 1}
    even_odd_count(123) ==> {1, 2}
*/
#include <stdio.h>
#include <math.h>
#include <string>
#include <vector>
using std;
vector < int > even_odd_count(int num) {
   
   vector < int > even;
   vector < int > odd;
   
   while (num > 0) {
      if (num % 2 == 0) {
         even.push_back(num % 10);
      }
      else {
         odd.push_back(num % 10);
      }
      num = num / 10;
   }
   return even;
}

<|endoftext|>/*
Find how many times a given substring can be found in the original string. Count overlaping cases.
>>> how_many_times("", "a")
0
>>> how_many_times("aaa", "a")
3
>>> how_many_times("aaaa", "aa")
3
*/
#include <stdio.h>
#include <string>
using std;
int how_many_times(string str, string out2) {
    int out = 0;
   
    for (int i = 0; i < str.size(); i++) {
        for (int j = 0; j < out2.size(); j++) {
            if (str[i] == out2[j]) {
                out++;
            }
        }
    }
    return out;
}

>>> how_many_times("", "a")
0
>>> how_many_times("aaa", "a")
3
>>> how_many_times("aaaa", "aa")
3
*/
#include <stdio.h>
#include <string>
using std;
int how_many_times(string str, string out2) {
    int out = 0;
   
    for (int i = 0; i < str.size(); i++) {
        for (int j = 0; j < out2.size(); j++) {
            if (str[i] == out2[j]) {
                out++;
            }
        }
    }
    return out;
}

<|endoftext|>/*
Given a positive floating point number, it can be decomposed into
and integer part (largest integer smaller than given number) and decimals
(leftover part always smaller than 1).

Return the decimal part of the number.
>>> truncate_number(3.5)
0.5
*/
#include <stdio.h>
#include <math.h>
using std;
double truncate_number(double x)
{
    int int_part;
    double decimal;
    double remainder;

    int_part = floor(x);
    remainder = x - int_part;
    decimal = remainder;
    return decimal;
}

<|endoftext|>/*
Concatenate vector of strings into a single string
>>> concatenate({})
""
>>> concatenate({"a", "b", "c"})
"abc"
*/
#include <stdio.h>
#include <vector>
#include <string>
using std;
string concatenate(vector < string > strings) {
   
   string result;
   
   for (string s : strings) {
      result += s;
   }
   
   return result;
}
/*
Count the number of times a character appears in a string
>>> count_chars("abcabc", a)
2
>>> count_chars("abcabc", b)
1
*/
#include <stdio.h>
#include <vector>
#include <string>
using std;
int count_chars(string s, char c) {
   int count = 0;
   
   for (char i : s) {
      if (i == c) {
         count++;
      }
   }
   
   return count;
}
/*
Count the number of times a substring appears in a string
>>> count_substring("abcabc", "ab")

>>> count_substring("abcabc", "bc")
1
*/
#include <stdio.h>
#include <vector>
#include <string>
using std;
int count_substring(string s, string sub) {
   int count = 0;
   
   for (char i : s) {
      if (i == sub[0]) {
         for (char j : sub) {
            if (j == s[i]) {
               count++;
            }
         }
      }
   }
   
   return count;
}

<|endoftext|>/*
Filter an input vector of strings only for ones that start with a given prefix.
>>> filter_by_prefix({}, "a")
{}
>>> filter_by_prefix({"abc", "bcd", "cde", "vector"}, "a")
{"abc", "vector"}
*/
#include <stdio.h>
#include <vector>
#include <string>
using std;
vector < string > filter_by_prefix(vector < string > strings, string prefix) {
   
   vector < string > result;
   
   for (string & s : strings) {
      if (s.substr(0, prefix.length()) == prefix) {
         result.push_back(s);
      }
   }
   
   return result;
}

/*
Filter an input vector of strings only for ones that end with a given suffix.
>>> filter_by_suffix({}, "a")
{}
>>> filter_by_suffix({"abc", "bcd", "cde", "vector"}, "a")
{"abc", "vector"}
*/
#include <stdio.h>
#include <vector>
#include <string>
using std;
vector < string > filter_by_suffix(vector < string > strings, string suffix) {
   
   vector < string > result;
   
   for (string & s : strings) {
      if (s.substr(s.length() - suffix.length(), suffix.length()) == suffix) {
         result.push_back(s);
      }
   }
   
   return result;
}

/*
Filter an input vector of strings only for ones that contain a given substring.
>>> filter_by_substring({}, "a")
{}
>>> filter_by_substring({"abc", "bcd", "cde", "vector"}, "a")
{"abc", "vector"}
*/
#include <stdio.h>
#include <vector>
#include <string>
using std;
vector < string > filter_by_substring(vector < string > strings, string substring) {
   
   vector < string > result;
   
   for (string & s : strings) {
      if (s.find(substring)!= string::npos) {
         result.push_back(s);
      }
   }
   
   return result;
}

<|endoftext|>/*
Return true if a given number is prime, and false otherwise.
>>> is_prime(6)
false
>>> is_prime(101)
true
>>> is_prime(11)
true
>>> is_prime(13441)
true
>>> is_prime(61)
true
>>> is_prime(4)
false
>>> is_prime(1)
false
*/
#include <stdio.h>
using std;
bool is_prime(long long n) {
    if (n < 2) return false;
   
    long long i = 2;
    long long is_prime = true;
    
    while (i * i <= n) {
        if (n % i == 0) {
            is_prime = false;
            break;
        }
        i += 1;
    }
    return is_prime;
}

<|endoftext|>#include<stdio.h>

#include<vector>
using namespace std;
double poly(vector<double> xs, double x){
    /* 
    Evaluates polynomial with coefficients xs at point x. return xs[0] + xs[1] * x + xs[1] * x^2 +.... xs[n] * x^n 
    */
    double sum=0;
    int i;
    for (i=0;i<xs.size();i++)
    {
        sum+=xs[i]*pow(x,i);
    }
    return sum;
}

<|endoftext|>/*
The Fib4 number sequence is a sequence similar to the Fibbonacci sequnece that's defined as follows:
fib4(0) -> 0
fib4(1) -> 0
fib4(2) -> 2
fib4(3) -> 0
fib4(n) -> fib4(n-1) + fib4(n-2) + fib4(n-3) + fib4(n-4).
Please write a function to efficiently compute the n-th element of the fib4 number sequence.  Do not use recursion.
>>> fib4(5)
4
>>> fib4(6)
8
>>> fib4(7)
14
*/
#include <stdio.h>
using std;
int fib4(int n) {
    int b [ 100 ];
    b [ 0 ] = 0;
    b [ 1 ] = 0;
    b [ 2 ] = 2;
   
    for(int i = 3; i <= n; i++) {
        b [ i ] = b [ i - 1 ] + b [ i - 2 ] + b [ i - 3 ] + b [ i - 4 ];
    }
    return b [ n ];
}

    a [ 1 ] = 1;

    }

}

{1, 4, 2, 4, 3}
*/
#include <stdio.h>
#include <vector>
using std;
vector < int > intersperse(vector < int > numbers, int delimeter) {
    vector < int > result = {
        }
    ;
    if (numbers.size() > 0) result.push_back(numbers [ 0 ]);
    for (int i = 1; i < numbers.size(); i++)
   
        result.push_back(numbers [ i ]);

        result.insert(result.begin() + i + 1, delimeter);
    
    return result;
}

Input to this function is a string represented multiple groups for nested parentheses separated by spaces.
For each of the group, output the deepest level of nesting of parentheses.
E.g. (()()) has maximum two levels of nesting while ((())) has three.

>>> parse_nested_parens("(()()) ((())) () ((())()())")
{2, 3, 1, 3}
*/
#include <stdio.h>
#include <vector>
#include <string>
using std;
vector < int > parse_nested_parens(string paren_string) {
    vector < int > all_levels;
    string current_paren;
    int level = 0, max_level = 0;
    char level2;
    int i;
    for (i = 0; i < paren_string.length(); i++)
     {
        level2 = paren_string [ i ];
        if (level2 =='')
         {
            level+=1;
           
         }
         else if (level2 == '(')
         {
            if (level > max_level)
             {
                max_level = level;
                current_paren = paren_string.substr(0, i);
             }
            level+=1;
         }
         else if (level2 == ')')
         {
            if (level == max_level)
             {
                all_levels.push_back(max_level);
             }
            level-=1;
         }
         else
         {
            cout << "Invalid input" << endl;
            exit(1);
         }
     }
    return all_levels;
}

}

            }
            i++;
        }
        else
        {
            return false;
        }
    }
    return true;
}

<|endoftext|>/*
Filter an input vector of strings only for ones that contain given substring
>>> filter_by_substring({}, "a")
{}
>>> filter_by_substring({"abc", "bacd", "cde", "vector"}, "a")
{"abc", "bacd", "vector"}
*/
#include <stdio.h>
#include <vector>
#include <string>
using std;
vector < string > filter_by_substring(vector < string > strings, string substring) {
    vector < string > out;
   
    for(auto & s : strings) {
        if(s.find(substring)!= string::npos) {
            out.push_back(s);
        }
    }
    return out;
}

<|endoftext|>/*
Create a function encrypt that takes a string as an argument and
returns a string encrypted with the alphabet being rotated. 
The alphabet should be rotated in a manner such that the letters 
shift down by two multiplied to two places.
For example:
encrypt("hi") returns "lm"
encrypt("asdfghjkl") returns "ewhjklnop"
encrypt("gf") returns "kj"
encrypt("et") returns "ix"
*/
#include <stdio.h>
#include <string>
using std;
string encrypt(string s) {
    string out;
    int c;
   
    for(int i=0; i<s.length(); i++) {
        c = s[i];
        if(c>='a' && c<='z') {
            c = c + 2;
        }
        if(c>='A' && c<='Z') {
            c = c - 2;
        }
        out += c;
    }
    return out;
}

/*
Create a function decrypt that takes a string as an argument and

The alphabet should be rotated in a manner such that the letters 
shift down by two multiplied to two places.
For example:

decrypt("ewhjklnop") returns "asdfghjkl"
decrypt("kj") returns "gf"
decrypt("ix") returns "et"
*/
string decrypt(string s) {
    string out;
    int c;
   
    for(int i=0; i<s.length(); i++) {
        c = s[i];
        if(c>='a' && c<='z') {
            c = c - 2;
        }
        if(c>='A' && c<='Z') {
            c = c + 2;
        }
        out += c;
    }
    return out;
}

/*
From a given vector of integers, generate a vector of rolling median element found until given moment
in the sequence.
>>> rolling_median({1, 2, 3, 2, 3, 4, 2})
{1, 2, 2, 2, 2, 2, 2}
*/
#include <stdio.h>
#include <vector>
using std;
vector < int > rolling_median(vector < int > numbers) {
    vector < int > out;
    int mid = numbers.size()/2;
    int sum = 0;
   
    for(int i = 0; i < numbers.size(); i++) {
        if(i < mid) {
            sum += numbers[i];
        }
        else {
            sum += numbers[i-mid];
        }
    }
    out.push_back(sum / numbers.size());
    
    for(int i = 0; i < numbers.size(); i++) {
        if(i < mid) {
            sum += numbers[i];
        }
        else {
            sum += numbers[i-mid];
        }
        out.push_back(sum / numbers.size());
    }
    return out;
}

}

        sum += pow(numbers[i] - numbers[i-1], 2);
        out.push_back(sqrt(sum / numbers.size()));
    }
    return out;
}

You are given a vector of integers.
Write a function next_smallest() that returns the 2nd smallest element of the vector.
Return None if there is no such element.

next_smallest({1, 2, 3, 4, 5}) == 2
next_smallest({5, 1, 4, 3, 2}) == 2
next_smallest({}) == None
next_smallest({1, 1}) == None
*/
#include <stdio.h>
#include <vector>
#include <algorithm>
using std;
int next_smallest(vector < int > vector) {
   
   if(vector.size() == 0)
      return 0;
   
   if(vector.size() == 1)
      return vector[0];
   
   if(vector[0] < vector[1])
      return vector[1];
   
   if(vector[0] > vector[1])
      return vector[0];
   
   vector<int>::iterator it;
   it = find(vector.begin(), vector.end(), vector[0]);
   
   if(it == vector.end())
      return 0;
   
   vector<int>::iterator it2;
   it2 = find(vector.begin(), vector.end(), vector[1]);
   
   if(it2 == vector.end())
      return 0;
   
   if(*it < *it2)
      return *it;
   
   return *it2;
}

Examples
any_int(5, 2, 7)  true

any_int(3, 2, 2)  false

any_int(3, -2, 1)  true

any_int(3.6, -2.2, 2)  false



*/
#include <stdio.h>
#include <math.h>
using std;
bool any_int(float a, float b, float c2) {
    if (round(a)!= a) return false;
   
    if (round(b)!= b) return false;
   
    if (round(c2)!= c2) return false;
   
    if (round(a+b+c2)!= a+b+c2) return false;
   
    return true;
}

<|endoftext|>/*
Given a map, return true if all keys are strings in lower 
case or all keys are strings in upper case, else return false.
The function should return false is the given map is empty.
Examples:
check_map_case({{"a","apple"}, {"b","banana"}}) should return true.
check_map_case({{"a","apple"}, {"A","banana"}, {"B","banana"}}) should return false.
check_map_case({{"a","apple"}, {"8","banana"}, {"a","apple"}}) should return false.
check_map_case({{"Name","John"}, {"Age","36"}, {"City","Houston"}}) should return false.
check_map_case({{"STATE","NC"}, {"ZIP","12345"} }) should return true.
*/
#include <stdio.h>
#include <string>
#include <map>
using std;
bool check_dict_case(map < string, string > dict) {
    map < string, string > :: iterator it;
    int islower = 0, isupper = 0;
    if (dict.size() == 0) return false;
    for (it = dict.begin(); it!= dict.end(); it++)
     {
        string key = it -> first;
       
        if (key.size() == 0) return false;
        if (islower(key[0]) == islower) {
            islower++;
        }
        if (isupper(key[0]) == isupper) {
            isupper++;
        }
    }
    if (islower == dict.size() || isupper == dict.size()) {
        return true;
    }
    return false;
}
